Dietary diversification consists of introducing foods other than breast milk or infant formula. It should be started for all children between 4 and 6 months of age.

Its nutritional value is marginal, as almost all the nutritional needs of infants up to the age of 12 months are met by their mother's milk or infant formula.

The role of diversification is mainly to introduce :

- new food proteins to help them acquire tolerance,

- new flavours for optimal taste development,

- pieces to encourage the development of chewing,

- fibre to help the intestinal microbiota adapt to a diet that is not exclusively milk-based.

question.title: When should dietary diversification be introduced?
question.description: What age range should dietary diversification be started for?

option_a.title: 6-8 months
option_a.description: Starting dietary diversification at this age range allows infants to acquire tolerance to new food proteins and develop optimal taste

option_b.title: 4-6 months
option_b.description: Dietary diversification should be introduced at this age range to encourage the development of chewing and intestinal microbiota adaptation

option_c.title: 12-14 months
option_c.description: Dietary diversification should be introduced at this age range to provide infants with a balanced diet that meets their nutritional needs

option_d.title: After 12 months
option_d.description: Dietary diversification should be introduced at this age range to ensure infants acquire tolerance to new food proteins and develop optimal taste
